poem:
Assisted Departure  

in gentle hands  
rest desires—  
no soaring halls,  
no gavel's echo  
to shepherd  
kind release;  

the world's edge  
is a quiet place  
where whispers  
turn to wings.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ex-supreme court judge says high court signoff for assisted death unnecessary A former supreme court judge has told MPs that applications for assisted dying should not need high court approval. Lord Sumption told a committee scrutinising the assisted dying bill that the requirement for signoff by a high court judge was “unnecessary and in some respects undesirable”. No other jurisdiction in the world that allows assisted dying has such a requirement, he said. The terminally". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
